## Ordinal outcomes



### Example 

The Kessler-6 items. Here we employ a categorical model in which the observed variable y has a probability of being equal to response option + 1 latent thresholds. An ordinal model assumes that an observed ordinal indicator measures a latent continuous variable \cite{Burkner2019-ie,Hadfield2012-hi}. The Kessler-6 has five ordinal response options for indicating frequency of feeling distress during the past 30 days: "None Of The Time", "A Little Of The Time", "Some Of The Time", "Most Of The Time", "All Of The Time" hence six thresholds. The Kessler-6 distress indicators are: "Feeling Hopelessness;" "Feeling so Depressed Nothing Could Cheer You Up;" "Feeling Nervous or Fidgety;" "Feeling Everything is an Effort;" "Feeling Worthless;" "Feeling Nervous." We simultaneously modelled each of these six outcomes within a single model. 


$$\begin{align}
y^k \sim \text{Ordered}(\mu_t^k) \\
\text{CumLogit}(\mu_t^k) = \alpha_t^k +\beta^k \\
\alpha_t^k = \alpha_{t0}^k +\alpha^k_c \\
\alpha_{t0}^k \sim \text{StudentT}(3,0,10)\\
\alpha_c^k \sim \text{StudentT}^+(3,0,10)\\
\boldsymbol{\beta^k}\sim \text{Normal}(0,1) 
\end{align}$$

Below, the superscript $k$ is denotes the $k = 1\dots6$ Kessler-6 outcomes. Residuals for cumulative categorical models are not identified, so are fixed to 1. $\alpha_{j0}^k$ denotes the $t = 1\dots 5$ intercepts estimated for the ordinal model, which assumed a cumulative logit distribution for the outcome, and where the lowest response level is modelled as zero, hence four intercepts are estimated for each Kessler- 6 response indicator. $$\mathbf{\beta}$$ denotes the individual-level predictors.

## Ordinal predictors (Monotonic effects)

```{r}
system.time(
  m1 <- brm(
    bf(HLTH.Fatigue_int  ~
      Covid_Timeline_cr),
    family = cumulative(link = "logit"),
    data = nz,
    file = here::here("models", "ordinal_fatigue"),
    silent = FALSE
  )
)
summary(m1)
par_m1 <-parameters::model_parameters(m1)
plot(par_m1)
plot(
  conditional_effects(
    m1,
    spaghetti = TRUE,
    nsamples = 100,
    categorical = F,
    select_points = 0.1,
    prob = 0.89,
    re_formula = NA,
  ),
  points = TRUE,
  point_args = list(alpha = 0.1,
                    width = .02)
) #  
```


## Random intercept

```{r}
system.time(
  m1_l <- brm(
    bf(HLTH.Fatigue_int  ~
      Covid_Timeline + (1|Id),
    family = cumulative(link = "logit"),
    data = nzl,
    file = here::here("models", "ordinal_fatigue_longitudinal"),
    silent = FALSE
  )
)
summary(m1_l)
par_m1_l <-parameters::model_parameters(m1_l)
plot(par_m1_l)

plot(
  conditional_effects(
    m1_l,
    spaghetti = TRUE,
    nsamples = 100,
    categorical = F,
    prob = 0.89,
    re_formula = NA,
  ),
  points = TRUE,
  point_args = list(alpha = 0.1,
                    width = .02)
) #  note this command controls which facet 

plot(ggeffects::ggpredict(m1_l), add.data= TRUE, dot.alpha = .1)

system.time(
  m_k6_s <- brm(
    bf(KESSLER6sum  ~
      Covid_Timeline + (1|Covid_Timeline/Id)),
      data = nzl,
    file = here::here("models", "k6_longitudinal"),
    silent = FALSE
  )
)

system.time(
  m_k6_s0 <- brm(
    bf(KESSLER6sum  ~
      Covid_Timeline + (1|Id)),
      data = nzl,
    file = here::here("models", "k6_longitudinal_0"),
    silent = FALSE
  )
)

system.time(
  m_k6_p <- brm(
    bf(KESSLER6sum  ~
      Covid_Timeline + (1|Id), family = "poisson"),
      data = nzl,
    file = here::here("models", "k6_longitudinal_p"),
    silent = FALSE
  )
)
summary(m_k6_s)
summary(m_k6_s0)

par_m_k6_s <-parameters::model_parameters(m_k6_s,dispersion = TRUE, effects = "random")
plot(par_m_k6_s,  type = "re", sort = TRUE, horizontal = TRUE) 
plot(par_m_k6_s,  type = "fe", sort = TRUE, horizontal = TRUE) 

plot(
  conditional_effects(
    m_k6_p,
    spaghetti = TRUE,
    nsamples = 100,
    categorical = F,
    prob = 0.89,
    re_formula = NA
  ),
  points = TRUE,
  point_args = list(alpha = 0.1,
                    width = .02)
) # 



plot(
  conditional_effects(
    m_k6_s0,
    spaghetti = TRUE,
    nsamples = 100,
    categorical = F,
    prob = 0.89,
    re_formula = NA
  ),
  points = TRUE,
  point_args = list(alpha = 0.1,
                    width = .02)
) # 

plot(ggeffects::ggpredict(m_k6_p), add.data= TRUE, dot.alpha = .1)

```
